thread.title: The Bachelorette Australia 2015: Why is Michael on the show? |
thread.title_full: The Bachelorette Australia 2015: Why is Michael on the show? | The Courier-Mail

author: couriermail.com.au
title: The Bachelorette Australia 2015: Why is Michael on the show? |
text:
Viewers — who were clearly as enamoured by the 34-year-old as Sam Frost was last night — were left asking themselves that question after he emerged as one of the 14 blokes vying for Sam’s heart on the Channel Ten dating series.
The retired athlete, who last played as goalkeeper for the Melbourne Victory in the A-League, was also a member of the Australian squad at the Sydney 2000 Olympics, has played for Belgium’s Standard Liège, Bristol City, The New Zealand Knights and the Brisbane Strikers before winning the A-League Grand Final with Melbourne Victory in April this year.
It’s a pretty impressive resume for any athlete, let alone one who has good looks, a fit bod and a charming personality to boot.
So why would a man like Michael need to sign up to a reality show to find love? Michael made an immediate impact on Sam. Picture: Tara Croser Source: News Corp Australia
“I haven’t found the right girl yet,” he told news.com.au, before cryptically adding, “things happen for a reason and the fact I ended up on this show could be that reason.”
It was clear to viewers from the get-go that Michael was one of the frontrunners, with a preview of what lies ahead showing the pair on several steamy dates together.
Could that mean he may have stolen Sam’s heart?
“It’s all been extremely positive and something that will stay with me forever,” Michael said. “It’s an amazing experience and when you get to meet someone like Sam it makes it even better. Sam and myself were there for the right reasons and when you’re on the same page it just works. It was a really incredible experience.”
So wait a minute, does that mean Sam will stay with him forever?
He’s playing coy. Michael during a Melbourne Victory training session with teammate Lawrence Thomas. Picture: Mark Dadswell Source: News Corp Australia
Michael played in the Grand Final for Melbourne Victory. Source: Supplied
“I went in with no strategy or game plan and when I had the opportunity to talk to Sam at the first cocktail party we got along quite well. In terms of being a top contender or frontrunner, I don’t know about that, but I certainly felt quite comfortable with her.”
But don’t think that cocktail parties, elaborate dates and hanging out with 14 guys in a mansion is a walk in the park.
Michael says it was very hard emotionally on the men and even thinks the guys have a rougher time dealing with the challenges of the dating show environment than the girls.
“Guys find it just as hard but they hide it,” he said. “When we are smiling and laughing, inside we could be stressing but we hold it in, whereas girls might let it out with a few tears. Michael during the FFA Cup match between Broadmeadow and Brisbane Strikers at Wanderers Oval on July 29, 2014. Source: Getty Images
“It’s very, very hard opening up and talking to a complete stranger about who you are and what you’re looking for, that’s really private stuff. You’d normally talk about that five or six months into a relationship, not with someone you’ve just met. That’s the challenge and the fact that you’ve got 13 other guys looking over your shoulder doesn’t make it any easier.”
So now that he’s bared his soul to the nation, what do his football mates think of him signing up to a reality show and getting all gushy about his quest to find love?
“I’ve had so much support and encouragement, not just from my football mates, but everyone, they’ve all said ‘good on you for putting yourself out there and saying what you want’, it’s not easy in the real world let alone in that type of environment.
“I think all the boys deserve a pat on the back on back for putting themselves out there and going for it. It’s not easy.” Michael in one of his more dreamy moments. Source: Instagram
Originally published as Why does this guy need reality TV to score?
